source_node.query: (US Treasury 5Y yield OR US Treasury 5-year yield OR US 5Y Treasury yield OR US 5-year Treasury yield OR UST 5Y yield OR UST5Y yield OR UST 5-year yield OR UST5-year yield OR 5Y Treasury yield OR 5-year Treasury yield OR 5Y Treasury bond yield OR 5-year Treasury bond yield OR US Treasury yield OR US Treasury yields OR US Treasury bond yield OR US Treasury bond yields OR 5Y Treasury OR 5-year Treasury OR 5Y Treasury bond OR 5-year Treasury bond) AND (news OR analysis OR report OR update OR trend OR market OR movement OR volatility OR change OR shift OR impact OR forecast OR outlook)
source_node.name: US 5Y Treasury Yield
source_node.fundamental_analysis:
UST 10‑year yields (ust10y) are projected to settle in a 4.5 % ± 0.5 % band over the next 12–18 months, with a modest upward bias if the Fed’s balance‑sheet contraction accelerates or inflation expectations fail to anchor (HYJA10SKI). The break in the historic Fed‑cut–yield relationship (fed_policy) is now evident: after the Fed’s three 25‑bp cuts from September 16‑17 2024 to December 2024, 10‑year yields rose rather than fell, a pattern that has persisted into the first quarter of 2025 (HYJA10SKI). This reversal is driven by the simultaneous acceleration of quantitative tightening, which has removed a substantial amount of demand‑side support from the Treasury market (us_treasury_supply), and by a structural change in the expectations channel, whereby market participants now view Fed cuts as a signal of higher future inflation rather than lower borrowing costs (HYJA10SKI). The Fed’s balance‑sheet contraction, which has been removing roughly $2 trillion of assets from the market since the peak of the QE program, has further pushed yields upward by tightening the supply‑side of the Treasury market (HYJA10SKI). Inflation expectations (us_inflation) remain elevated, as reflected in the persistent 30‑year mortgage rates (us_mortgage_rates) that have hovered near 7 % since the Fed began cutting rates in September 2024 (LF0UUL917). Because 30‑year mortgage rates are a close proxy for 10‑year Treasury yields, this indicates that ust10y yields are likely to stay in the 4–5 % band for the foreseeable future (LF0UUL917)(HYJA10SKI). The national debt (us_debt), which continues to grow at a pace that outstrips fiscal consolidation, adds further upward pressure on long‑term rates, as the market prices in higher default risk and higher borrowing costs (LF0UUL917). Loan demand, while still robust, has not been sufficient to offset the combined effects of higher inflation expectations and a shrinking supply of Treasury securities, keeping the term premium wide (LF0UUL917).  

Key risks to this outlook include a sudden spike in headline inflation, which would force the Fed to raise the federal funds rate and potentially widen the spread between short‑ and long‑term rates even further (LF0UUL917); a significant fiscal stimulus package or an unexpected surge in debt issuance, which could push long‑term yields higher by increasing supply and raising the perceived risk premium (LF0UUL917); geopolitical events that disrupt global capital flows, tightening global liquidity and compressing the Treasury market, creating a short‑term pull‑back in yields (HYJA10SKI); and a reversal in the Fed’s policy stance—if the Fed abandons quantitative tightening in favor of an accommodative stance—restoring the traditional transmission mechanism and leading to a rapid decline in long‑term rates (HYJA10SKI). The Fed’s September 16‑17 2024 meeting will be the primary catalyst for short‑term rates, but its impact on ust10y will be muted unless the market perceives a change in the balance‑sheet trajectory (HYJA10SKI). Inflation data released in Q3 2025, particularly core CPI (us_core_cpi) and PCE (us_pce) measures, will be critical in confirming whether the inflation expectations that underpin the term premium remain elevated (LF0UUL917). Monitoring the pace of the Fed’s balance‑sheet contraction and the Treasury market’s supply‑side dynamics will also provide early warning of any shift in the long‑term rate trajectory (LF0UUL917). Confidence in this view is moderate‑high, given the clear structural break in the Fed‑rate–yield relationship and the persistent macro‑fundamental drivers that support a high‑yield environment for ust10y (HYJA10SKI)(LF0UUL917).
